Speaker: commentator
Dialogue: "Returning to England are Britain's acting royalty Sir Laurence Olivier and Lady Olivier, better known as stunning Gone With The Wind star Vivien Leigh. Sir Laurence has added a new string to his bow with the announcement that he is to direct and star in a screen version of Terence Rattigan's stage play The Sleeping Prince with none other than Hollywood siren Marilyn Monroe. When the world's greatest actor romances the most famous woman alive, we can be sure that sparks will fly. Now, now Lady Olivier, don't worry - any romance is strictly for the camera!" As OLIVIER and VIVIEN smile for the photographers, we -

Speaker: kenneth
Dialogue: ... and this is one of Carracci's earlier works and one is able to see the emergence of his now famous Baroque style, which is clearly rooted in the tradition of high renaissance and antiquity... COLIN pauses briefly and hurries towards them. Throughout the scene there is a sense of his urgency and desire to go. The whole thing should be played at breakneck pace. KENNETH beams affectionately.

Speaker: kenneth
Dialogue: Colin! Come in. Have you met James and Anna? Two very brilliant pupils. He has the avuncular air of a benign academic, affable and a little eccentric. COLIN smiles hurriedly at the students, no time to waste.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I'm leaving for London now, Pa.

Speaker: kenneth
Dialogue: Ah, yes. Well, bon chance, dear boy... He puts a friendly arm around COLIN's shoulder and starts to walk him back to the door.

Speaker: kenneth
Dialogue: I can always get you a research position at the V&A when you've grown up a bit and got this film idea out of your system... COLIN's smiles but before he can reply JANE CLARK whirls into the room, a ball of energy, talking nineteen to the dozen.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Kenneth, you might have told Cook we were another two for dinner. What is everyone supposed to eat? Cabbage soup? Oh, Colin, darling, there you are...

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I'm off now, Mama.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Off?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: My job interview, remember..? But she is already continuing her journey. COLIN smiles hurriedly at KENNETH, who gives him an affectionate wave as COLIN dashes after his mother. She leaves the Library.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Can't you stay for dinner? There's nothing to eat but I'm sure the conversation will be charming.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I don't want to be late in the morning. As COLIN hurries after JANE he is nearly run down by an elderly GARDENER with a lawn mower, and has to take lightning evasive action. JANE doesn't notice.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I'm sure they won't mind. You'll be a famous film director in no time. I know your father's put in a word.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I wish he hadn't done that. I can manage on my own. She stops so abruptly he nearly slams into her. JANE looks around the garden with a frown.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: I have to watch Jenkins like a hawk. One more of his murderous prunings and we'll lose the tea roses for ever. And she's off again, with COLIN still following. He can't help smiling at the madness of it all.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Now go and have a lovely time, darling. We're always here when you're ready to talk your future. COLIN wants to protest but before he can get the words out JANE sees a YOUNG GARDENER walking at the side of the house with a wheel barrow. Her face lights up.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Mullins! Be an angel - find Cook and ask her how many pork chops we need for tonight. Then bring the car round. I must get to the village before the shop shuts... She dashes away after the GARDENER, turning back as an afterthought to blow a kiss at COLIN as she goes. COLIN smiles, then pauses for a moment to look at the house. We can sense both his affection for it but more pressingly his need to get away. He gets in, puts the car in gear and the Bristol pulls out of the drive and across the moat. In the last rays of the sun, the countryside looks magical, but Colin only has eyes for the road ahead.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: You're not in Mr. Perceval's diary.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Larry told me to come. She pauses dubiously, then reaches for her telephone. We hear a man answer in an office down the hall, his voice carrying irritably.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: I have a Mr. Colin Clark here. He says Sir Laurence sent him. She stresses the proper name in disapproval of Colin's familiarity.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Well, what do you want?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: A job on your Marilyn Monroe film.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Oh really, what as?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I want to work on the production side. He smiles with as much charm as he can muster. PERCEVAL isn't impressed.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: There are no jobs yet. We don't start shooting for eight weeks.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: May I wait?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Until there's a job.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: For eight weeks?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Something might come up. PERCEVAL is distracted as the telephone rings.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Terry? Larry wondered how the script was coming...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: There are no jobs.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I'll come back tomorrow morning. Just in case.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: It's a free country. He sounds as though he rather regrets it.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: Are you going to sit there all day?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: If I have to.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: You're very determined.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I'd do anything to be in the film business.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: Anything?

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: You can start by making me a cup of tea. White, two sugars.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: You can answer the telephone while I'm at lunch, if you like. She winks. COLIN grins. The phone rings. He picks it up.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Laurence Olivier Productions...

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: He's at Notley until the end of the week. Can I take a message?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Vanessa asked me to...

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Oh, did she? Why didn't you put that call through?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: There didn't seem any need to bother you. But if you want me to transfer every single one... PERCEVAL looks at him grudgingly.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Use your judgement. He hesitates and looks back.

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: Colin, darling! How are you getting on?

Speaker: jane
Dialogue: How exciting. Let me see... it's Sloane 2965. Ask him if he's coming to Saltwood for the bank holiday.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I will. Mama, you're an angel.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: That was quick.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I had a bit of luck. PERCEVAL looks at him shrewdly.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Am I supposed to be impressed? Did Mummy and Daddy help? Don't think they can do the job for you. The only way you'll get on in this business is through bloody hard work.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Yes, sir. COLIN leaves.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Do you know, Hughie, it is simply impossible to get Marilyn Monroe on the telephone? The darling girl spends the entire day asleep. But great beauty has its way... He laughs, but then notices VIVIEN's less than enthusiastic response. Seeking refuge in some distraction he notices COLIN hovering by the sofa.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: You remember Colin, darling. You met him at the Clarks' party.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: You said there might be a job on your film. OLIVIER has no recollection of this and fumbles in his pockets to cover his confusion, bringing out a packet of cigarettes and offering them to COLIN with breezy charm.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Have a cigarette. Keep the pack. He turns quickly to PERCEVAL.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: The House Committee are threatening to withhold Miller's passport. They say he's a communist. No Arthur, no Marilyn.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: I'll have a word with the American ambassador. I'm taking him to see Vivien in South Sea Bubble on Thursday... now, tell me, Hughie, are Terry's rewrites in? He puts an arm around PERCEVAL's shoulders and they disappear together into Perceval's office. VIVIEN lingers behind, smiling radiantly at COLIN who looks dumbly at the packet of cigarettes in his hand. He now sees they are called "Oliviers". VIVIEN wrinkles her nose in amusement.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: They named them after Larry. The first actor since Du Maurier to have his own brand and they pay him an absolute fortune.  I'm afraid they're rather ghastly. She cups Colin's cheeks with her hands and studies him in mock awe.

Speaker: vanessa
Dialogue: I suppose he's all right. VIVIEN's eyes sparkle. OLIVIER emerges from the office with a handful of script pages and VIVIEN looks at him slyly, getting her own back for his tactless over-praise of Marilyn's charms as she strokes COLIN's cheek.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Let's try to find him something to do, Hughie. COLIN grins in triumph. VIVIEN smiles at him.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: You will take care of my precious Larrykins, won't you? She flirtatiously offers up her cheek for COLIN to kiss. COLIN's smile falters as he sees PERCEVAL looking at him grimly.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Arthur Jacobs, Miss Monroe's publicist is flying in tomorrow. He wants to see the house she'll be staying in. Find something suitable.

Speaker: cardiff
Dialogue: Exactly - we need to tone her down a bit.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: How the hell do you tone down Marilyn Monroe?! COLIN laughs. He immediately regrets it. Both men turn to look at him. PERCEVAL turns off the projector and gazes at him stonily.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Marilyn Monroe's publicist is flying in tomorrow. He wants to see the house she'll be staying in. Find something suitable. COLIN nods eagerly, anxious to get out. He is already at the door when PERCEVAL barks at him again.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: And leave the bloody tea. COLIN had forgotten the tray. He blushes furiously, puts it down and hurries out.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: We'd pay a hundred pounds per week for 18 weeks.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: That's a pity. I'll have to tell Miss Monroe to look elsewhere, then. COTES-PREEDY double takes.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: It's Marilyn Monroe in the film. COTES-PREEDY smiles transparently.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. Jacobs. I hope you had a pleasant flight.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Where's the fucking car?

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Jeez, do you Brits actually read this stuff? He winds down his window and simply throws the whole lot out into the lane. The pages billow out in a great cloud behind the speeding car, landing in the pretty hedgerows and on neat front lawns. COLIN gapes in astonishment. Welcome to Hollywood.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: What is this place? A brothel? COTES-PREEDY's face falls.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Jesus. And I thought you Brits had taste.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: It's very near Pinewood.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: All right. We'll take it.  But ditch the wallpaper. It's given me a migraine.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: News travels fast.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: That house was perfect for Marilyn.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: We can't use it now.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Yes we can. I knew Cotes-Preedy wouldn't be able to keep this quiet. They stare to him in surprise. He looks at them boldly.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: When you asked me to find a house for Miss Monroe I took the precaution of finding two. The other one, Parkside, is much better and the owner is very discreet.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: But now we have two expensive houses when we only wanted one.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I thought someone else on the production might want it.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Oh, did you? There is a dangerous moment when things could go either way. COLIN has gambled everything in a bid to impress them.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: I guess Milton could use it. It's near the studio, near Marilyn. OLIVIER looks at COLIN, then bursts out laughing.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: What are we paying you, boy? He glances at COLIN with amusement.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Nothing...

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Colin Clark. Sir Laurence Olivier Productions.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: The set decorators will have it all sorted out in no time.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Marilyn hates red. And blue.  And green.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: What about white?

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: I'd have to clear it with her. OLIVIER glances mischievously at Colin.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Beige, then. Beige is rarely controversial. JACOBS considers this, unaware that Olivier is teasing him.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: I guess that's okay. She's never said nothing about beige. Paula will need the room next door.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Paula?

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Strasberg. Marilyn's acting coach. OLIVIER looks at him darkly. JACOBS shrugs.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Stanislavski and the Method are perfectly fine in the rehearsal room but they don't belong on a film set. Time is too tight. I'm sure Marilyn understands. He turns and walks away. JACOBS frowns uncertainly.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Who the hell is this Commie Stan Slavski?

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: I don't know why Hugh Perceval sent you here. There's nothing I can do for you.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Are you in the union?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Then you can't have a job on the film.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: How do I get in the union?

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: By getting a job on the film.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: But you just said I couldn't have a job on the film unless I was in the union.

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Exactly. It's called a closed shop. COLIN looks at him helplessly. ORTON relents a little.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: A third?

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Third Assistant Director.  You do know what the job is?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Assisting the director?

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Christ, no! That's the last thing you do. Lesson One. The third's job is to do whatever the fuck I tell him. ORTON walks to the door, then looks back.

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Colin! COLIN jumps as ORTON glowers at him.  ORTON  Lesson Two. You don't shit on your own doorstep. Got it?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Got it. But he sneaks a look back at LUCY as he goes.

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: Where are you staying?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: My father's place in the Albany.

Speaker: orton
Dialogue: You can forget that. Lesson Three. The Third always stays nearby, not in some bloody palace in London.  Book a room at the Dog And Duck down the road. It's a bit rough but you'll get used to it. He grins, enjoying himself.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: I'm sure you understand the sensitive nature of the job, Superintendant?

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: No need for the title. I'm retired from the force.  Something about looking after a cinema actress?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Not just any actress. Marilyn Monroe. He gets no reaction from the stolid ex-policeman.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: I've never had much time for the pictures.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Excellent.  For the next four months you never leave her side, day or night. There will be crowds.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: That doesn't bother me. PERCEVAL pauses awkwardly.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Her behaviour is reputedly a little... erratic.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: She drinks?

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Amongst other things.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: Pills? PERCEVAL leaves a tactful pause.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: It would be useful if you could keep us informed of her... domestic situation.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: You want me to spy on her? Perceval and Roger understand each other perfectly.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Just the odd early warning if you know she's going to be late on set. That kind of thing. Smith takes this in his stride; he seems wholly immune to the glamour of the movies.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: You need to speak to the Coca-Cola people, Larry. They're crazy to be involved with Marilyn. PERCEVAL and COLIN meet them coming the other way.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: Good news. The House Committee have decided Miller isn't a communist after all.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Of course he is. All those pain in the ass New York intellectuals are reds. OLIVIER rolls his eyes behind JACOBS back. COLIN grins.

Speaker: perceval
Dialogue: It means Marilyn will be flying in next week on schedule.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: She'll have to be met.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Naturally, Vivien and I will be there to greet her. But let's keep it low key, shall we?

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Don't worry. I've got it all under control.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: It is a deep happiness to me to be translating Terence Rattigan's magnificent play to the screen... A voice suddenly rings out from the back of the previously attentive crowd.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: The plane's landed! As one, the entire crowd turns away from Olivier and rushes towards the plane. Suddenly abandoned, OLIVIER and VIVIEN look momentarily startled before VIVIEN glances at him with a half-smile.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: It seems we're not top of the bill anymore, darling.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: There she is! Marilyn! The REPORTERS surge forward. COLIN follows their collective gaze. She looks exactly as she should. The radiant smile, the platinum blonde hair, the sexy wiggle. The most famous film star in the world, so much herself it is almost unreal. Walking through the crowd MARILYN smiles easily, whereas MILLER looks stern and a little dazed by the sudden flurry of attention. Flashbulbs pop as the POLICE struggle to contain the crowd. MARILYN puts her arm around MILLER, who grins blankly. The flashbulbs burst in front of them, a solid wall of dazzling light.

Speaker: reporter 2
Dialogue: Marilyn, this way..! ARTHUR JACOBS observes the chaotic scenes with obvious relish, grinning towards ROGER and COLIN.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Beautiful. You're looking at tomorrow's front page, boys. ROGER looks at COLIN.

Speaker: roger
Dialogue: We have to get them to the hall. COLIN barges his way through the scrum behind ROGER and briefly finds himself directly in front of MARILYN. For a moment he is transfixed by her beauty and charisma but she doesn't even see him as she follows the commanding ROGER obediently, tugging Miller along behind her, leaving Colin in her wake.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: It's my genuine pleasure to introduce a woman who needs no introduction.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: How do you like being married, Marilyn?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: I like it a lot.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Is this third time lucky?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: You bet it is. Arthur's the greatest man I ever met. OLIVIER smiles tolerantly, mildly put out at this. MARILYN takes off her sunglasses and blinks. She takes MILLER's arm and looks at him adoringly. He bites down savagely on his unlit pipe.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Marilyn, are you planning to see the sights?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: I'd love to see the little fellow with the bow and arrow in Piccadilly Circus. There is a appreciative laughter from reporters.

Speaker: reporter 2
Dialogue: Is it true you want to be a classical actor now?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: I want to be the best actress I can be.

Speaker: reporter 2
Dialogue: There's a rumour you're going to be in The Brothers Karamazov on Broadway.

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: I'm considering it.

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: I'll be playing Grushenka.

Speaker: reporter 3
Dialogue: Can you spell that?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: Sure. Can you? There is laughter at the reporter's expense.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: So would you say you're an intellectual now?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: My husband is. She looks adoringly at Miller, who smiles vaguely.

Speaker: reporter 2
Dialogue: What's your definition of an intellectual, Marilyn?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: I guess you could look it up in a dictionary. This time the laughter is emphatically on MARILYN's side. One of the reporters turns to VIVIEN.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Vivien, you created the part of Elsie Marina on stage. Do you have any advice for Marilyn?

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: I am sure if Miss Monroe needs any advice she'll get it from her director. I hear he's terribly good. The reporters laugh with her and OLIVIER smiles graciously. But as she smiles at him we detect just a flicker of jealous hurt in her eyes. OLIVIER intervenes quickly to continue his prepared speech of welcome.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: In The Sleeping Prince we have discovered the perfect vehicle for Miss Monroe's luminous and justly celebrated talent... He stops as a REPORTER shouts over him.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Marilyn, is it true you wear nothing in bed except Chanel No

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: As I'm in England let's say I sleep in nothing but Yardley's Lavender.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: Are all your press conferences like that, darling?

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: Well, that was quieter than some. Vivien smiles at the wry joke. ARTHUR JACOBS watches the proceedings with an eagle eye.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: Okay, let's get a snap of the newlyweds. Smile, Arthur. It's not a firing squad. As the group breaks up, MILTON GREENE, handsome and dark- haired, now approaches OLIVIER and COLIN.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: This is some place you found. He glances at the house. Olivier smiles generously.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: You have my new assistant Colin to thank for that.  This is Milton Greene. You must be very nice to him. He owns half of Marilyn Monroe Productions.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: Forty nine per cent, Larry. GREENE  offers them a tired smile. OLIVIER produces one of his branded packets and offers a cigarette to Milton.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Have a cigarette.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: I don't smoke. If he notices the "Olivier" name he doesn't show it. OLIVIER looks mildly put out.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Milton - Marilyn and rehearsals. Let's talk.

Speaker: milton
Dialogue: Sure. And the studio wants a new title. OLIVIER escorts Milton away. MILLER and MARILYN are now being photographed on their own. ROGER moves over to JACOBS and murmurs discreetly in his ear. JACOBS nods and moves in to end the session.

Speaker: jacobs
Dialogue: The boys at the gate are getting restless.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Let's give them two minutes and then we're done. ROGER waves to the POLICEMEN, who open the gates. The PRESS come pouring in like a mob of revolutionaries storming the Bastille.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: Marvellous, isn't she? I suppose you're quite smitten. COLIN looks at her shrewdly, sensing he is being tested.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: She's all right. A bit common.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: But she's only been married three weeks.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: Oh, Colin, I thought you were a man of the world. She gives him an arch smile and leans in intimately.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I'm sure he loves you very much. There is a flash of sudden anger in her expression.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: Oh, don't be such a boy! COLIN looks shaken and she touches his hand in contrition.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Of course. Everyone does. There is a wintry bleakness in her face for a second.

Speaker: vivien
Dialogue: I'm 43, darling. No one will love me for much longer. Not even you. He goes to protest but she stills him with a finger to his lips, her smile quickly restored.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Colin Clark. I booked a room. BARRY takes a dusty ledger from beneath the bar, spins it around for COLIN to sign.

Speaker: barry
Dialogue: What brings you up this way?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: I'm here working on a film. The LOCALS look up from their pints, unimpressed.

Speaker: barry
Dialogue: What film's that?

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: It's called `The Sleeping Prince'. The darts player, ANDY, doesn't turn. His aim remains steady.

Speaker: andy
Dialogue: Sounds lousy.

Speaker: barry
Dialogue: Ignore, Andy - not a film fan - are you, Andy? ANDY doesn't look away from his game.

Speaker: andy
Dialogue: Can't be bothered. COLIN tries to impress.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Marilyn Monroe's in it. I'll be working with her.

Speaker: barry
Dialogue: Oh, will you now? The regulars grin unkindly into their pints. ANDY doesn't look away from his game, as he offers laconically:

Speaker: andy
Dialogue: The Queen and Prince Philip popped in for a pint earlier. Pity, you just missed them. There are supportive snorts of derision from the LOCALS. COLIN takes it on the chin. BARRY hands him a key.

Speaker: barry
Dialogue: The room's three quid a week, first week in advance. You're in number two. COLIN takes the key and his bag, just as BARRY adds, with perfect deadpan timing:

Speaker: wattis
Dialogue: What a wonderful adventure, Dame Sybil.

Speaker: sybil thorndike
Dialogue: Such a lark! I long to see her. COLIN stands by the door. OLIVIER looks at his watch and shoots him a questioning glance.

Speaker: colin
Dialogue: Miss Monroe? The door opens sharply and a small, bohemian looking woman in her 50s stands staring at him. This is PAULA STRASBERG.

Speaker: readthrough
Dialogue: He glances beyond PAULA to where MARILYN sits by the mirror, her reflection framed in the lights. She wears little or no make-up. PAULA looks at him sharply.

Speaker: paula
Dialogue: But Marilyn is not ready. She's preparing. MARILYN glances up at COLIN in the mirror and smiles with unexpected simplicity.

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: Excuse the horrible face. She finds her dark glasses on the dresser and puts them on.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Marilyn, here you are, everyone is so excited to meet you... He gestures to the company.

Speaker: sybil thorndike
Dialogue: How lovely you are. Here, I kept a place for you. PAULA bursts forward, steering Marilyn away instead to an empty seat on the other side of the rectangle of tables. She looks at RICHARD WATTIS, the actor occupying the seat next to the empty one.

Speaker: paula
Dialogue: I have to be next to Marilyn! The startled WATTIS gets up graciously and troops all the way around the table to the seat next to SYBIL THORNDIKE.

Speaker: paula
Dialogue: She likes me by her side.

Speaker: sybil thorndike
Dialogue: What a good idea! I wish we could all bring a friend. One does get so terribly nervous. It's just like the first day at school, isn't it?

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: Welcome dear Marilyn, to our little fraternity.  We may seem a little strange and quaint to you at first, but I hope that in time you may come to find your method in our madness. Pleased with his over-contrived rhetorical flourish, he gives Paula a pointed look. She glowers back, obscurely sensing that she has been insulted in some way. MARILYN also looks up in confusion at Olivier's well intentioned but clumsy joke. Oblivious to her reaction, he opens his script with a sentimental flourish.

Speaker: marilyn
Dialogue: Gee, Mister Sir, I could listen to your accent all day. There are private grins amongst the actors. OLIVIER smiles kindly.

Speaker: olivier
Dialogue: You are amongst friends, my darling angel. Just plain Larry will suffice.  When you're ready..? Flustered, MARILYN looks at her script.

Speaker: paula
Dialogue: Remember why you're in the embassy, Marilyn. What does the Grand Duke want from Elsie? She thought there were going to be a lot of people here and it's just her. OLIVIER waits patiently.
